title: 107_s1035
content: The "Great Lakes Preservation Act" may be cited as the official title of this legislation. The Act includes findings related to the Great Lakes region. Congress finds that the Great Lakes are crucial public natural resources, vital for the economies of the Great Lakes States, and provide safe drinking water for millions of people. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 is a voluntary international agreement that provides a procedural framework for notice and consultation by the Great Lakes States and Provinces regarding water diversion. Governors and Premiers base decisions on water proposals on conservation and protection of the Great Lakes basin's natural resources. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 emphasizes the importance of water conservation and protection of the basin's natural resources. Decision-making regarding Great Lakes water is entrusted to the Governors of the Great Lakes States. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 emphasizes water conservation and protection of natural resources, with decision-making entrusted to the Governors of the Great Lakes States. SEC. 3 defines key terms. The Act defines key terms related to water conservation, including the terms "Administrator," "bulk fresh water," and "from the Great Lakes basin." The Act defines key terms related to water conservation, including the term "Great Lake" which refers to Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, and Lake Ontario. It also includes water from interconnecting waterways and tributaries that drain into these lakes. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec, Canada, while the term "Great Lakes State" includes Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Moratorium on export of bulk fresh water. Moratorium on export of bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin within the United States, with a provision for sunset upon approval of a conservation standard by Governors and Premiers. The Federal Government should make an agreement with Canada to uphold the moratorium on exporting bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin until a specified date. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC GREAT LAKES LIGHTHOUSES. Congress finds that the Great Lakes have played a significant role in the history of the region, with lighthouses serving as important navigational aids. Many of these lighthouses hold historical or architectural value, but their future is uncertain due to neglect and deterioration. The Great Lakes lighthouses are in poor condition due to neglect and deterioration. The Secretary will conduct a study within 3 years to identify options for preservation and consult with the National Park Service to ensure the lighthouses are preserved. The Secretary will consult with State and local historical associations, historic preservation agencies, the Coast Guard Commandant, and other appropriate entities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funding.
